results.title: City water supply
results.brief_description: Illustrates the relation between rainfall and life. The sources of a city’s water supply - wells, rivers, lakes and watersheds - are also illustrated and the film goes on to study both the varied methods which are employed to distribute water throughout a city, and the methods used to prevent the spread of disease and epidemics through water-borne bacteria.
results.description: Illustrates the relation between rainfall and life. results.title: city school diary_05
results.brief_description: An anonymous digital dairy created by a young person as part of a day long workshop run by ACMI. Each diary is scripted and a voiceover recorded by the individual young person. Some diaries use photographs brought in by the participant, but the primary visual content is often black and white, ‘stock’ footage of a poetic nature. At no point should the creator or school be positively identified when screening this work.

results.title: City of the sixties
results.creator_credit: Cinesound, Brisbane City Council and Stuart Glover
results.brief_description: Made for the Brisbane City Council showing the advances and achievements reached by capital of Queensland, Brisbane. Contains short clips of the Council’s activities such as roads and public transport, health, childcare etc as well as a celebration of cultural achievements of the city.

results.title: City of the angels
results.creator_credit: Keith Adam, Australian Broadcasting Commission and Geoffrey Barnes
results.brief_description: In the late 18th century, Rama I, first of the great Chakri kings, ordered his architects to build a new capital for Thailand - Bangkok. In Thai, Bangkok is called the “City of Angels”. Today one tenth of Thailand’s population lives in Bangkok, the most urbanised city in Thailand, which contains all the elements of Thai life seen in the extreme. Presenter Keith Adam, takes us on a tour of this city of contrast, a city of canals, superb temples and palaces alongside bustling markets, traffic jams, pollution and poverty.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Keith Adam, Australian Broadcasting Commission and Geoffrey Barnes
